div.p: As it was lately Acted by her Maiesties Seruants, at the Phenix in Drury Lane.
LONDON. Printed for Iohn Groue, and are to be sold at his shop at Furniualls Inne Gate in Holborne. 1629.

list.label: Sir Iohn Belfare.
Beauford, a passionate louer of Gratiana.
Marwood friend to Beauford.
Rawbone a thin Citizen.
Lodam a fat Gentle-man.
Iustice Landby.
Captaine Landby.
Isaac, Sir Iohns man.
Hauer a yong Gentle-man, louer of Mistresse Iane.
Cameleon, Rawbones man.
Physition.
Keeper.
Surgeon.
Seruants.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT Worshipfull William Gowre, Esquire.
div.p: SIR, I know you, and in that your worth, which I honor more then greatnesse in a Patron: This Comedy comming forth to take the ayre in Summer, desireth to walke vnder your shaddow. The World oweth a perpetuall remembrance to your name, for excellency in the Musicall Arte of Poesie, and your singular iudgement and affection to it, haue encouraged me to this Dedication, in which I cannot transgresse beyond your Candor. It hath passed the Stage; and I doubt not but from you, it shall receiue a kinde welcome, since you haue beene pleas'd to acknowledge the Author.

div.head: To his learned and much respected friend, Mr. Iames Shirley, vpon his Wedding.
div.l: AN inforc'd rapture, and high swelling phrase
Doth onely gaudy ignorance amaze;
Conceites that yeelde iudicious Writers glory,
Enrich the beauty of thy Comicke Story:
Loues passion in smooth numbers is descride,
Such as becomes the softnesse of a Bride.
I want a Poets aëry soule, to giue
Due prayses to thy lines, which shall out-liue
The Crittickes spleene, the Atheists impious iest;
A modest pen becomes the Muses best,
And such is thine, as thy faire Wedding showes,
Who Crownes thee not, a debt to knowledge owes.

div.head: To his worthy Friend Mr. Shirley, vpon his Nuptiall Comedy.
div.l: IS Beaumont dead? or slept he all this while,
To teach the World the want of his smooth stile?
If he be dead, that part of him Diuine
By transmigration of his soule is thine:
High is thy fancy, yet thy straine so sweete,
Death would be lou'd in such a winding sheete:
This Wedding needes no Offering, and thy worth
Is aboue flattery, to set thee forth:
From whose rich Muse thus Wedded, we shall see
Many faire Children borne to Poësie.

lg.l: Dies fugaci de siliunt pede
Nec vrna cuiquam parcit, at improbae
Viuit superstes fama morti,
Nec gelidum metuit sepulchrum.
O qui ingales flauus Hymen toros
Ambis, coruscâ iam nitidus togâ
Incede, Shirleiana laurus,
Perpetuos tibi dat triumphos.
Phoebus sacrata vellit ab arbore
Ramum, modestas quo decoret comas
Additque vatem Laureatis
Sideribus, numerumque claudit.
SPread faire thou growing Tree, with which in vaine
The windes do wraste: blemish'd with the staine
Of impure life, some by Atheisticke rimes,
And witty surfeits, force these ruder times
To fond amazement; but thy faire defence
Rests in cleare Arte, and secure Innocence.
As thou, thy Muse is chast, on which no Rape
Was ere by thee committed, Learnings Ape
Is franticke imitation; and the Bough
That Crownes such Writers, withers on their brow:
I gratulate thy Wedding; Loue doth guide
My friendly Muse, thus to salute thy Bride.

div.head: To my deseruing friend Mr. Iames Shirley, vpon his Comedy, the Wedding.
div.l: THou need'st not, friend, that any man for thee,
Should to the World put in security.
Thy Comedy is good; 'twill passe alone,
And faire enough, without this ribbands showne
Vpon the fore-head on't: if high rays'd passion
Temper'd with harmelesse mirth, in such sweet fashion,
And with such harmony, as may inuite
Two faculties of soule, and both delight
Deserue an approbation, in mine eye,
Such in iust value is this Comedy.

div.head: Of this Ingenious Comedy the Wedding. To Mr. Iames Shirley the Author.
div.l: THE Bonds are equall, and the Marriage fit,
Where iudgement is the Bride, the Husband wit;
Wit hath begot, and iudgement hath brought forth
A noble issue, of delight, and worth,
Growne in this Comedy to such a strength
Of sweete perfection, as that not the length
Of dayes, nor rage of mallice, can haue force
To sue a nullity, or worke diuorce
Betweene this well trim'd Wedding, and loud Fame,
Which shall in euery age, renew thy Name.

div.head: Actus Primi. Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Belfare, and Isaac his man, seruants bringing in Prouision.

sp.speaker: Belfare.
sp.p: WEll done my Masters, yee bestirre your selues, I see we shall feast to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your worship shall want no Wood-cockes at the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thou hast as many as thou canst carry, and thirteene to the last dozen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Haue you beene carefull, to inuite those friends, you had direction for?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Yes sir, I haue beene a continuall motion euer since I rise.
I haue not sayd my prayers to day.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: We shall want no guests then.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I haue commanded most on'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I ha'bid 'em sir, there's two in my list, will not fayle to dine w'ee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Master Rawbone, the yong vsurer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Oh hees reported a good Trencher-man,
He has a tall stomacke, he shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: They say, he has made on Obligation to the Diuell, if euer he eate a good meale at his owne charge, his soule is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How does he liue liue?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Vpon his mony sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He does not eate it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No the Diuell choake him, it were a golden age, if all the Vsurers in London should ha'no other dyet; hee has a thingut waytes vpon him, I thinke, one of his bastards, be got vppon a spider, I hope to liue, to see 'em both drawne through a ring.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who is the other?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The other may be knowne too, the barrell at Heidelberg was the patterne of his belly, Master Lodam sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hee's a great man indeede.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Something giuen to the wast, for he liues within no reasonable compasse I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: They will be well met.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But very ill matcht to draw a Coach, yet at prouender, there wilbe scarce an Oate betweene the leane jade, and the fat Gelding.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How liues he?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Religiously sir; for hee that seedes well, must by consequence liue well, hee holds none can be dam'd but leane men, for fat men he sayes must needes bee sau'd by the faith of their body.

div.stage: Enter Mr Beauford, and Captaine Landby.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mr. Beauford and Captayne Landby: Isaac, call forth my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, I hope you make no stranger of me,
To morrow, I shall change my title for
Your sonne, soone as the holy rites shall make me
The happy husband to your daughter, in the meane time
It will become me wayte on her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I possesse nothing but in trust for thee,
Gratiana makes all thine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I shall presume to follow.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your friendship noble Captaine to Mr. Beauford,
Makes your person most welcome,
Had you no other merit, pray enter. Exe. Bea. & Cap.
Heauen hath already crownd my gray hayres!
I liue to see my daughter married
To a noble husband, the enuye of our time,
And exact patterne of a Gentleman,
As hopefull as the Spring, I am growne proud,
Euen in my age. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dost heare sirra?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I sirra.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is Master Beauford within?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was inform'd he came hither, is he not here?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou sayst he's not within.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: No sir, but tis very like he wilbe to morrow night sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Would you haue him be within before he is married.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Witty Groome, prethee inuite him forth; say here's a friend

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Now you talke of inuiting, I haue two or three guests to inuite yet: let me see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why dost not mooue?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: And you make much adoe, ile inuite you: pray come to the. Wedding to morrow. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Belfare, Beauford, and Captaine.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Tis hee.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: You were my happy prospect from the window, Coose you are a most welcome guest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mr. Marwood, you haue beene a great stranger to the City, or my house for the course entertaynement you receiu'd, hath beene vnworthy of your visit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Twas much aboue my desert sir: Captayne.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I congratulate your returne.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Beauford, Gentlemen enter my house,
And perfect your embraces there: I lead the way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Pray follow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your pardon.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: We know you haue other habit,
You were not wont to affect ceremony. Mar. & Bea whisper.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I do not like his present countenance,
It does threaten somewhat; I wo'd not prophesie.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Good Captayne,
Excuse my absence to our friends within,
I haue affayres concernes me with my kinsman,
Which done, we both returne to wayte on 'em.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Now proceed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We are kinsmen.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: More we are friends.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And shal I doubt to speak to Beauford any thing,
My loue directs me to?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What needs this circumstance?
Wee were not wont to talke at such a distance,
You appeare wild.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I haue beene wilde indeede
In my vngouernd youth, but ha' reclaimd it,
And am to laden with the memory of former errours,
That I desire to be confest.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Confest? I am no Gostly father.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But you must heare, you may absolue mee too:

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: If thou hast any discontentments prethee take other time
For their discourse, I am in expectation of Marriage,
I would not interrupt my ioyes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I must require your present hearing,
A concernes vs both, as neere as fame, or life.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha! what is it?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Wee shall haue opportunity at your lodging,
The streetes are populous and full noise,
So please you walke, Ile wait one you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ime your seruant. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Milisent. Where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In complement with Mr. Rawbone, who is newly entred sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: O there's a peece of folly.
A thing made vp of parchment and his bonds
Are of more value then his soule and body,
Were any man the purchaser, onely wise
In his hereditary trade of vsury,
Vnderstands nothing but a scriuener,
As if he were created for no vse
But to grow rich with intrest, to his ignorance,
He ha's the gift, of being impudent,
What will he grow to, if he liue, that is
So young a monster?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: With your fauour sir
If you hold no better opinion of this Citizen
It puzles, mee why you inuite him, to your house
And entertainement, he pretending affection to your daughter,
Pardon me sir if I seeme bold.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: As some men Milisent
Do suffer spiders in their Chamber, while
They count them profitable vermine.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But he's most like to scatter poyson sir,
Your fame is precious, and your family
Not mingling with corrupted streames, hath like
An entire Riuer, still maintayn'd his current
Chast, and delightfull.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Sha't receiue my bosome,
Ile sooner match her with an Ethiope,
Then giue consent, she should disgrace our blood;
And herein I but trye her strength of iudgement
In giuing him accesse; if she haue lost
Remembrance of her birth, and generous thoughts,
She suck'd from her dead mother, with my care
Ile striue to reinforce her natiue goodnesse,
Or quite diuorse her from my blood: and Milisent
Ile vse your vigilance.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Sir command.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I will,
Not vrge how I receiu'd you first a stranger,
Nor the condition of your life, with me,
Aboue the nature of a seruant, to
Obliege your faith: I haue obserued thee honest.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You are full of noble thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Though I suspect not
The obedience of my daughter, yet her youth
Is apt to erre, let me employ your eye
Vpon her still, and receiue knowledge from you,
How she dispenceth fauours, you shall binde
My loue the stronger to you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Sir, I shall be ambitions to deserue your fauour
Withall the duties of a seruant, and
I doubt not, but your Daughter is so full
Of conscience, and care in the conformity
Of her desires to your will, I shall
Inrich my sight with obseruation,
And make my intelligence happy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How now: what's he?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Tis Mr. Rawbones squire.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray is not my Masters worship here?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Your Masters worship!
What's that, his Spaniell?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No sir, but a thing that does follow him.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: In what likenesse,
I hope he does not conuerse with spirits.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Heele not entertayne an Angell,
But he will weigh him first, indeede
I am all the spirits that belong to him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: So I thinke, but none of his familiar.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Good; didst euer eate?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes once.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And then thou caught'st a surfeit,
thou couldst nere endure meate since: wer't euer christned.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes twice, first in my infancy,
And the last time about a yeare agoe,
When I should haue beene prentise to an Anabaptist.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Does thy Master loue thee?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, for, and I would gold I might haue it,
But my stomacke would better digest beefe, or mutton,
If there be any such things in nature.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Here is his Master sir, and Mistris Iane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: How now Cameleon, hast din'd?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes sir,
I had a delicate fresh ayre to dinner.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: And yet thou lookst as thou hadst eate nothing this se'night, here prouide me a Capon, and halfe a dozen of Pidgeons to supper, and when will your worship come home, and tast my Hospitality.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: When you please sir,

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Yet now I thinke on't,
I must feede more sparingly.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: More liberally in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Would not any body in the world thinke so? did you euer see two such eare-wigges as my man and I: doe wee not looke like.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: I thinke the picture of eyther o'your faces in a ring, with a Memento mors, would be as sufficient a mortification, as lying with an Anotomy.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: The reason why wee are so leane and consum'd, is nothing, but eating too much: Cameleon now I thinke on't, let the Pygeons alone, the Capon will bee enough for thee and I.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The rumpe would last vs a se'night.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I tell you forsooth, I ha brought my selfe so low, with a great dyet, that I must be temperate, or the Doctor sayes there's no way but one wo'me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That's not the way of all flesh I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: It is a shame to say, what we eate euery day.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: I thinke so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: By this hand: if it would beare an oath: wee haue had nothing this two dayes but halfe a Larke; which by a mis-chance the Cat had kild too, the Cage being open: I will prouide my belly another Master.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Now Ile interrupt em Master Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I hope your Worship will repinie my boldnesse,
Tis out of loue to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Sir, I haue a businesse to you, a friend of mine vpon some necessity would take vp a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ile pawne some ounces to pleasure him.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: It is more friendly sayd then I expected.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: So he bring me good security, some three or
Foure, or fiue sufficient and able Citizens, for
Mortalities sake, ile lend it him.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Will you not take an honest mans word.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Few words to the wise, I will take any mans word to owe me a hundred pound, but not a Lords to pay me fifty.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Well: tis curtesie.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: He shall pay nothing to me but lawfull consideration from time to time, beside the charges of th'ensealing, because he is your friend.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: This is extreamity, can you require more?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: More? whats eight in the hundred to me? my Scriuenes knowes, I haue taken forty and fifty in the hundred vijs̄ and modis of my owne kins-men, when they were in necessity.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I apprehend the fauour.
How now Isaac?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: My master commends his loue to you sir, and does desire your presence together with your Daughter and Nephew, at the arraignement of my young mistresse to morrow.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: How knaue?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Shee is to be married or arraign'd, ith' morning, and at night to suffer execution and loose her head.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Returne our thankes, and say wee'le waite vppon the Bride Iane. Exeunt Iustice and Iane.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Deare Master Rawbone, I doe beseech you bee at these Sessions.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Thou didst inuite me before.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: I know it, but our Cocke has a great minde, that sentence should likewise passe vppon the roast, the boyld, and the bak'd, and hee feares vnlesse you be a Commissioner, the meate will hardly bee condemn'd to morrow, so that I can neuer often enough desire your stomacke to remember, you will come.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Dost thinke I won't keepe my word?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Alas, wee haue nothing, but good cheere to entertayne you, I beseech you sir howsoeuer to feast with us, though you goe away after dinner.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: There's my hand—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Is master Iustice gone, and mistresse Iane too? follow me Cameleon. Ile take my leaue when I come agen.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My little wit, thou wo't come with thy master tomorrow, Ile reserue a bottle of wine to warme thy sconce.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I cannot promise.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
If I durst stay three minutes, I would venture a cup with thee irh' buttery, but tis a busie time at home:
Farewell Milisent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Marriage as much ioy waite vpon the Bride,
As the remembrance of it brings me sorrow,
A woman has vndone me, when I dye
A Coffin will enclose this misery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You prepare me for some wonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I doe:
And ere I come to the period of my Story,
Your vnderstanding will admire.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Teach my soule the way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am not Cose ith' number of those friends
Come to congratulate your present marriage.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am no flatterer, the blood you carry
Doth warme my veines, yet could nature be
Forgetfull and remoue it self, the loue
I owe your merit, doth oblige me, to
Relation of a truth which else would fire
My bosome with concealement. I am come
To deuide your soule, rauish all your pleasures,
Poyson the very ayre maintaynes your breathing,
You must not marry.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Must not? though as I
Am mortall I may be compeld within
A payre of minutes to turne ashes, yet
My soule already Bride-groome to her vertue,
Shall laugh at Death that would vnmarry vs,
And call her mine eternally.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Death is
A mockery to that diuorce I bring,
Come you must not loue her.

sp.speaker: Beau,
sp.l: Did I hope thou couldst
Giue me a reason, I would aske one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do not,
I will too soone arriue, and make you curse
Your knowledge, couldst exchange thy temper for
An angels, at the hearing of this reason,
'Twould make you passionate, and turne man agen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Can there be reason for a sinne so great,
As changing my affection from Gratiana?
Name it, and reach me how to be a monster,
For I must loose humanity, oh Marwood,
Thou leadst me into a Wildernesse, she is—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: False, sinnefull, a blacke soule she has.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou hast a hell about thee, and thy language
Speakes thee a Diuell, that to blast her innocence
Dost belch these vapours: to say thou lyest,
Were to admit, thou hast but made in this
A humane errour, when thy sinne hath aym'd
The fall of goodnesse. Gratiana false?
The snow shall turne a Salamander first
And dwell in fire; the ayre retreate, and leaue
An emptinesse in nature, angels bee
Corrupt, and brib'd by mortals sell their charity
Her innocence is such, that wert thou Marwood
For this offence condemn'd to lodge in flames,
It would for euer cure thy burning feauer,
If with thy sorrow thou procure her shed
One teare vpon thee, now, thou art lost for euer,
And arm'd thus, though with thousand furies guarded,
I reach thy heart. Drawes:

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Stay Beauford,
Since you dare be so confident of her chastity
Heare me conclude, I bring no idle fable
Patcht vp betweene suspition, and report
Of scandalous tongues, my eares were no assurance
To conuince me without my eyes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What horror!
Be more particular:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did prophesie,
That it would come to this, for I haue had
A tedious strugling with my nature, but
The name of friend ore-ballanc'd the exception:
Forgiue me Ladies, that my loue to man
Hath power to make me guilty of such language,
As with it, must betray a womans honour:

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You torture me, be briefe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then, though it carry shame to the reporters,
Forgiue me heauen, and witnesse an vnwelcome truth.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Stay, I am too hasty for the knowledge
Of something thou prepar'st for my destruction,
May I not thinke what tis, and kill my selfe?
Or at least by degrees, with apprehending
Some strange thing done, infect my fancy with
Opinion first, and so dispose my selfe
To death? I cannot, when I thinke of Gratiana
I enterrayne a heauen: the worst, Ile heare it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It will enlarge it selfe too soone, receiue it;
I haue enioyd her.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gratiana sinnefully, before your loue
Made she and you acquainted.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha? th'ast kept thy word thou canst so poison all
My comfort.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your friendship I ha preferred
To my owne fame, and but to saue you from
A lasting shipwrack, noble Beauford, thinke
It should haue rotted here, she that will part
With Virgin honour, nere should wed the heart.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Was euer woman good, and Gratiana
Vitious? lost to honour? at the instant
When I expected all my Haruest ripe.
The golden Summer tempting me to reape
The well growne eares, comes an impetuous storme
Destroyes an ages hope in a short minute,
And lets me liue, the copy of mans frailty:
Surely, some one of all the female sexe,
Engrost the vertues, and fled hence to Heauen,
Left woman-kind dissemblers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, make vse
Of reason, tis a knowledge should reioyce you,
Since it does teach you to preserue your selfe.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Enioyd Gratiana sinnefully, tis a sound
Able to kill with horror; it infects
The very aire, I see it like a mist
Dwell round about, that I could vncreate
My selfe, or be forgotten, no remembrance
That euer I lou'd woman: I haue no
Genius left to instruct me— it growes late:
Within—
Waite o'my kinsman to his Chamber,
I shall desire your rest, pray giue me leaue
To thinke a little—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cosen: I repent
I haue beene so open breasted, since you make
This seuere vse on't, and afflict your minde
With womanish sorrow, I haue but caution'd you
Against a danger, out of my true friendship:
Prosper me goodnesse as my ends are noble:
Good-night, collect your selfe, and be a man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And why may not a kinsman be a Vilaine?
Perhaps he loues Gratiana, and enuying
My happinesse, doth now traduce her chastity
To find this out, time will allow but narrow
Limits: His last words bad me be a man.
A man? yes I haue my soule, t'does not become
A manly resolution to be tame thus,
And giue vp the opinion of his mistresse
For one mans accusat on;— ha: ith' morning?
Proper. Yes Marwood I will be a man:
His sword, shall eyther make past the sence
Of this affliction. or mine enforce
A truth from him, if thou beest wrongd Gratiana
Ile ye thy Martyr, but if false, in this
I gayne to dye, not liue a sacrifice. Exit.

div.head: Actus Secundi. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To the Taylors man, runne.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: To the Taylors man,
Why not to his master?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The Wedding cloathes not brought
Home yet, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: W'o would trust of womans Taylor, take measure so long before of a Gentle-woman, and not bring home his commodity, there's no conscience in't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The arrant Shoe-maker too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Master Hide, is not he, come yet I cald vppon him yester-day, to make hast of my Mistresses shoes, and he told me, he was about the vpper leather, he would be at her heeles presently, I left his foot in the stirrop, I thought he would haue rid post after me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Prethee Isaac, make hast, how tedious th'art, hast not thou beene there yet.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh yes, and here agen, de'e not see me, you are so light your selfe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As thou goest, call vpon Cod the Perfumer, tell him he vses vs sweetly, has not brought home the gloues yet.— and dost heare? when th'art at the Peacocke remember to call for the sprig, by the same token I left my fanne to be mended:— and dost heare? when th'art there, tis but a little out of the way, to runne to the Diuell, and bid the Vintener make hast with the runlets of Claret, we shall ha no time to burne it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You need not if it come from Diuell, me-thinkes that Wine should burne it selfe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Runne I prethee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Taylors, Shoe-makers, Perfumers, Feather-makers, and the Diuell and all, what a many occupations does a woman runne through, before she is married. Exit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fye vpon't what a perplexity is about a Wedding, I might haue beene thus troubled for a child of my owne, if good lucke had seru'd.

lg.l: — Within. Cardona.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I come Lady-bird. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Was this your purpose.

sp.speaker: Bea,
sp.l: This place of all the Park affords most priuacy.
Nature has plac'd the trees to imitate
A Roman Amphitheater.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We must be the sword-players.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Draw, imagine all
These trees were Cypresse, the companions of
Our funerall, for one or both must go
To a darke habitation, me-thinkes
We two, are like to some vnguided men,
That hauing wandred all the day in a
Wild vnknowne path, at night walke downe into
A hollow grot, a caue which neuer Starre
Durst looke into, made in contempt of light
By nature, which the Moone did neuer yet
Be-friend with any melancholy beame:
Oh Cosen thou hast led me, where I neuer
Shall see day moue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is the way to make it
A night indeede, but if you recollect
Your selfe, I brought you beames to let you see
The horror of that darknesse you are going to,
By marrying with Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That name
Awakes my resolution, consume not
Thy breath too idly, th'ast but a small time
For th'use om't, eyther employ it in the vnsaying
Thy wrong to Gratiana, or thou hastens
Thy last minute.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I must tell Beauford them,
He is vngratefull to returne so ill
My friendship, haue I vnder-valued
My shame in the relation of a truth,
To make the man I woo'd preserue, my enemy:
Why dost thou tempt thy destiny with so
Much sinne? dost thinke I were a sword I dare
Not manage? or that I can be inforc'd
To a reuolt? I am no Rebell Beauford:
Againe I must confirme Gratianaes honour
Stain'd, the treasures of her chastity
Rifled, and lost, twas my vnhappinesse
To haue added that, vnto my other sinnes
ith' wildnesse of my blood, which thou mayst punish.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou hast repeated, but the same in
Substance touching Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Truth is euer constant
Remaines vpon her square, firme, and vnshaken.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: If what thou hast affirm'd be true, why should
We fight, be cruell to our selues, indanger
Our eternity, for the errour of
One frayle woman? let our swords expect
A nobler cause. What man hath such assurance
In any womans faith, that he should runne
A desperate hazard of his soule? I know
Women are not borne angels, but created
With passion and temper like to vs,
And men are apt to erre, and louse themselues
Caught with the soule of wanton beauty, fetterd
Euen with their mistresses haire

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like this well. aside.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: He has a handsome presence and discourse,
Two subtle charmes to tempt a womans frailty,
Who must be gouern'd by their eye or eare
To loue, beside my kinsman hath beene taxt.
For being too prompt in wantonnesse, this confirmes it
Then farwell woman kind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This does become you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why should we fight, our letting blood wo'not
Cure her, and make her honour white agen:
We are friends, repent thy sinne, and marry her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How Sir, marry her?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why canst tho adde to it another crime,
By a refusing to repayre the ruines
Of that chast temple, thou hadst violated?
Her Virgin tapers are by thee extinct,
No odour of her chastity, which once
Gaue a perfume to Heauen, and and did refresh
Her innocent soule, they that haue spoyld virginity,
Do halfe restore the treasures they tooke thence
By sacred marriage.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Marriage, with whom?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Should I marry a whore?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou lyest, and with a guilt vpon thy soule,
Able to sinke thee to damnation, drawes againe.
Ile send thee hence; a whore? what woman
Was euer bad enough to deserue that name?
Salute some natiue fury, or a wretch
Condemn'd already to hells tortures by it,
Not Gratiana; th'ast awakned iustice,
And giuen it eyes to see thy treachery,
The depth of thy malicious heart, that word, hath
Dis-inchanted me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you serious?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How haue I fin'd in my credulity
'Gainst vertue, all this while? what charme bound vp
My vnderstanding part, I should admit
A possibility, for her to carry
So blacke a soule; though all her sexe beside
Had fallen from their creation? thou hast
Not life enough to forfeit, what an aduantage
To fame and goodnesse had beene lost.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you fight?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Wert thou defenc'd with circular fire, more
Subtle then the lightning, that I knew would rauish
My heart, and marrow from me, yet I should
Neglect the danger, and but singly arm'd,
Flye to reuenge thy calumny: a whore— come on sir.
Th'art wounded: ha? Fight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mortally, flye Beauford, saue thy selfe, I hasten to the dead.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh stay a while, or thou wilt loose vs both,
Thy wound I cannot call backe, now there is
No dallying with heauen, but thou pulst on thee
Double confusion, leaue a truth behind thee,
As thou wouldst hope rest to thy parting soule,
Hast thou not wrong'd Gratiana?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, in my lust, but not in my report,
Take my last breath, I sinfully enioy'd her, One hollows within.
Gratiana is a blotted peece of alablaster:
Farewell least some betray thee, heauen forgiue
My offence, as I do freely pardon thine.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I cannot long suruiue,—
Is there no hope thou maist recouer?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Farewell for euer then, with thy short breath
May all thy ills conclude, mine but beginne
To muster, life and I shall quickly part,
I feele a sorrow will breake Beaufords heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: There are Cony-stealers abroad sir.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: These whorson Rabbet suckers
Will nere leaue the ground.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: In my walke last night, I frighted some on em.
Pox a these vermin, would they were all destroy'd.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: So we may chance to keepe no Deere.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: An old Cony stops a knaues mouth somtimes.
That else would be gaping for Venison.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Whos's that?

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: Here's a Gentle-man wounded.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: He has bled much.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: How came you hurt sir? no,
Not speake? if he be not past hope, let vs
Carry him to my lodge, my wife is a
Peece of a Surgeon, has beene fortunate
In some cures: teare a peece of thy shirt Raph,
To bind his wound quickly:— so, so, alas
Poore Gentle-man, he may hue to be drest, and tell
Who has done this mis-fortune: gently Exe. carry him in.
Honest Raph, he has some breath yet:
Would I had my blood-hound here.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Belfare Iustice Landby, and his daughter Iane, Isaac waiting.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Y'are welcome Mr Landby, and mistresse Iane.
Where's the young Captayn sir your Nephew?

sp.speaker: Iust
sp.l: He went betimes to waite vpon the Bridgroome.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: They are inseperable friends, as they had
Diuided hearts, they both are glad, when eyther
Meete a good fortune.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Ile be bold to see your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do mistresse Iane, she has
Her maides blush yet, she'le make you amends for this,
And ere't be long I hope 'dance at your wedding. Exit Iane.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I wish you many ioyes sir by this marriage:
Your daughter ha made discreet election,
She'le haue a hopefull Gentle-man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Master Landby,
It would refresh my age to see her fruitful to him,
I should finde a blessing for a young
Beauford, and be glad to dandle him, the
First newes of a boy borne by my daughter
Would set me backe seauen yeares: O Master Landby,
Old men do neuer truely doate, vntill
Their children bring em babies.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Rawbone, and Hauer as his seruant.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Master Rawbone, Ile be bold to present you
With a peece of Rose-mary, we ha such cheere.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Honest Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Pray do you belong to Master Rawbone?

sp.speaker: Hau
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You haue eate something in your dayes.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.l: Nothing, nothing,
D'ee vnderstand nothing, you shall eate nothing:
Vnlesse some Benefactors like my master,
In pitty of your bellies once a yeare
Do warme it with a dinner, you must neuer
Hope to see rost, of sod; he has within
This twelue month to my knowledge
Made seauen men immortall.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes, he has made spirits on em,
And they haunt such mens houses as my masters,
Spirits ath' buttery, let me counsell yee
To cram your corpes to day, for by his Almanacke
There's a long Lent a comming.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Neuer see me,
But when you are inuited.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: 'Las I had
Rather eate a peece of cold Capon at home,
Than be troublesome abroad. I hope forsooth
Mistresse Iane is as she shud be.

sp.speaker: Iust
sp.l: She is in health:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Y'aue a fresh seruant master Rawbone,
A proper fellow, and maintaines himselfe
Hansomely.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: And he wod not ha maintain'd
Himselfe, I had neuer entertaind him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Where's Cameleon?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I ha preferr'd him Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Turnd him away last night,
And tooke this stripling.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Morrow sir Iohn, where is the early Bridegroom?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Came not you from him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We expect him sir, euery minute.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Not yet come? his seruants told me
He went abroad before the morning blusht.

sp.speaker: Rel.
sp.l: We ha not seene him, pray heauen
He be in health.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I wonder at his absence.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Captayne Landby, young man of war, I do
Salute thee with a broad-side.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: D'ee heare, they
Say you come a woing to my Cosen,
That day you marry her, ile cut your throate,
Keep't to your selfe.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Thou art a noble fellow; things may prosper.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You come hither to wish God giue em ioy now.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Yes marry do I.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You do lye, you come to
Scoure your durty maw with the good cheere,
Which will be dam'd in your leane Barathrum,
That kitchin-stuffe deuourer.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Why shud you
Say so Captaine? my belly did nere thinke
You any harme.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: When it does vomit vp thy heart
Ile prayse it, in the meane time would
Euery bit thou eatst to day, were steept
In Aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: What is that Iasper?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: It is strong water.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Noble Captayne, thankes yfaith hartily:
I was afraid you had beene angry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ile ha thee sow'd vp in a
Mony-bagge, and boyld to ielly.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: You shall ha me at your seruice,
And my bags too, vpon good security:
Is not this better then quarrelling, Iasper,—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is not the Bride-groome come yet, sure he has ouer slept himselfe, there is nothing but wondring within, all the maydes are in vprore, one sayes he is a slow thing, another sayes, she knowes not what to say, but they all conclude, if euer they marry, they'le make it in their bargaine to be sure of all things before matrimony, fie vpon him, if I were to be his wife, i'de shew him a tricke for't, ere a yeare came about, or it should cost me a fall, I warrant him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Sir Iohn y'are troubled.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Can you blame me sir:
I would not haue our mornings expectation
Frustrate— I know not what to thinke.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Sir, feare not.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The morne growes old.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Himen has long tapers.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What should procure his absence; he departed
But odly yester-day.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Marwood had engag'd him,
They promis'd to returne.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But we see neither.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: They'le come together, make it not your feare,
Beauford's a Gentle-man, and cannot be
Guilty of doing such affront, vnlesse
Some mis-fortune—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That's another iealousie.

div.stage: Enter Lodam, Cameleon waiting vpon him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Where is Sir Iohn Belfare?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha? Master Lodam,
Welcome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I congratulate.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Saw you master Beauford sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes I saw him, but—

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not how he does,
Where is the Lady that must be vndone to night,
Your daughter?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My daughter vndone, name what vnhappines,
My heart already doth beginne to prophesie
How unkind fate, name what disaster, giue it
Expression pray, what is the newes?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The newes?
Why wo'd yee know the newes? tis none a'ch best.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Be temperate then in your relation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What ist?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: They say for certayne,
There were foure and twenty Colliers cast away,
Comming from New-Castle tis cold newes ith' Citty,
But there is worse newes abroad.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Doth it concerne my knowledge? trifle not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: They say that Canary sacke, must dance
Agen to the Apothecaries, and be sold for
Physicke, in hum-glasses, and thimbles, that the
Spaw-water must be transported hither, and
Be drunke insteed of French wines:
For my part, I am but one.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Big enough for two.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This citadell may endure as long a siege
As another, if the pride of my flesh must be
Puld downe, farewell it t'has done me
Seruice this forty yeare: let it goe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Saw you master Beauford?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes Sir Iohn,
I saw him but— twas three dayes agoe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hee is ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Doe not afflict your selfe,
He will giue a faire account at his returne.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray heauen hee may:
My daughter.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Sir, I desire to be acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I haue no stomacke sir to your acquaintance,
You are a thought too leane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: And you a bit too fat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dost not wonder girle at Beaufords absence?

sp.speaker: Grats.
sp.l: Not at all sir, I am not now to learne
Opinion of his noblenesse; and I hope
Your iudgements will not permit you sinne so much
To censure him for this stay. Faire morning
To master Landby, noble Captaine, master
Lodam, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I am so little
She cannot see me, giue you ioy forsooth,
I hope it is your destiny to be married.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And yours to bee hang'd.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: How sir.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: No harme,
He wishes you long life.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: A long halter he does,
What to bee hang'd.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Las sir he knows you ha no flesh to burden you,
Light at a feather, hanging will nere kill you,
If he had wish'd sir master Lodam hang'd.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then, ile to him and thanke him;
But here's mistresse Iane.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You shal command me as your seruant.— sirra. Exit. As he goes out, he sees Rawb. court Iane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I did but aske her how she did, I sayd
Neuer a word to her: Pox vpon his bounsing
I am as fearefull of him as of a Gun,
He does so powder me.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: We haue not seene
You sir, this great while, you fall away me-thinkes.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.l: Loosing Lodam I.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: You are not the least welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I do giue you great thanke, and do meane to dance at your Wedding for't, I doe maruaile Master Beauford is not earlier, I shud ha beene here with musique Lady, and haue fidled you too, before you were vp, these leane Louers, ha nothing in em, slow men of London.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gratiana. Lod spies Iane.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who's this? shee has a mortall eye.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Cameleon? How now turn'd away your master.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, I sold my place; as I was thinking to runne away, comes this fellow, and offered me a breake-fast for my good will to speake to my Master for him, I tooke him at his word, and resigned my Office, and turn'd ouer my hunger to him immediately; now I serue a man, Isaac.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Isaac.— Exit Isaac as sent off.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do fore-see a fall of this tower already,
Loue beginnes to vnder-mine it.
Mistresse, a word in priuate.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Iasper has't a sword.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: That's well, let it alone:
Didst see this paunch affront me?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: He did it in loue to the Gentle-woman.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: In loue? let me see the sword agen. Drawes.
Wo'd twere in his belly— put it vp,
Thou deserust a good blade, tis so well kept.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Master Beauford, master Beauford.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hard by, within a stones cast a my
Mistresse, here sit here. Enter Beauford.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: My deerest Beauford, where hast bin so long?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Oh Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Are you not in health?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not well, tis then no time to chide:
How fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I haue a trouble at my heart: pardon
The trespasse o' your patience Gentle-men,
He publish the occasion of my absence,
So first, you giue me leaue, to vnlade it here;
But with your fauour, I desire I may
Exempt all eares, but Gratianaes, till
A short time ripen it for your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Lets leaue 'em then a while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Into the Garden Gentle-men.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: With all my heart:
In my conscience the 'Ile be honest together.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This begets my wonder, master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good sir Iohn, ile waite vpon you,
It is dinner time. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I haue not time to dwell on circumstance,
I come to take my last leaue, you and I
Must neuer meete agen.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What language do I heare,
If Beauford it should strike me dead?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: This day, I had design'd for marriage, but I must
Pronounce wee are eternally diuorc'd:
Oh Gratiana, thou hast made a wound
Beyond the cure of Surgery, why did nature
Empty her treasure in thy face, and leaue thee
A blacke prodiglous soule?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Defend me goodnesse!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Call vpon darknesse, to obscure thee rather,
That neuer more thou maist be seene by mortall,
Get thee some dwelling in a mist, or in
A wild forsaken earth, a Wildernesse,
Where thou maist hide thy selfe, and dye forgotten.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Where was I lost name what offence prouok'd
This heauy doome, deare Beauford, be not so
Iniust, to sentence me, before I know
What is my crime, or if you will not tell
What sinne it is, I haue committed, great,
And horrid, as your anger; let me study,
Ile count em all before you, neuer did
Penitent, in confession, strip the soule
More naked, ile vnclaspe my booke of conscience,
You shall read ore my heart, and if you finde
In that great Volume, but one single thought
Which concern'd you, and did not end with some
Good prayer for you: Oh be iust and kill me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Be iust, and tell thy conscience, th'ast abus'd it
False woman, why dost thou increase thy horror?
By the obscuring a mis-deed, which wo'd
Were all thy other sinnes forgiuen, vndo thee
Oh Gratiana, thou art.—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A thing I would not name, it sound so fearfully,
'Twould make a Diuell blush, to be saluted
By that, which thou must answere to.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I feare—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That feare betrayes thy guilt, tell me Gratiana
What didst thou see in me to make thee thinke
I was not worthy of thee, at thy best
And richest value, when thou were as white
In soule, as beauty? for sure, once thou wert so:
Hadst thou so cheape opinion of my birth,
My breeding, or my fortunes, that none else
Could serue for propertie of your lust, but I?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Deare Beauford heare me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A common father to thy sinne-got issue,
A patron of thy rifled, vnchast wombe?
Oh thou wert cruell, to reward so ill
The heart that truely honor'd thee: thy name
Which sweetn'd once the breath of him that spake it,
And musically charm'd the gentle eare;
Shall sound here-after like a Screech-owles note,
And fright the hearer; Virgins shall lament
That thou hast sham'd their chast society,
And oft as Himen lights his tapers vp,
At the remembrance of thy name, shed teares,
And blush for thy dishonour: from this minute,
Thy friends shall count thee desperately sicke,
And whensoere thou goest abroad, that day
The maides and matrons, thinking thou art dead,
And going to the graue, shall all come forth
And waite like mourners on thee.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Ha yee done?
Then heare me a few sillables, you haue
Suspition that I am dishonourd.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: No,
By heauen I haue not, I haue too much knowledge
To suspect thee sinnefull, but in the assurance
Of it, I must disclayme thy heart for euer:
Gratiana my opinion of thy whitenesse
Hath made my soule, as blacke as thine already;
Weepe till thou wash away thy staine, and then,
ith' other world, we two, may meete agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Weepe inward eyes, hither your streames impart,
For sure, I haue teares enough, to drowne my heart. Exit.

div.head: Actus Tertij. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You amaze me Beauford, Gratiana false?
I shall suspect the truth of my conception,
And thinke all women monsters, though I neuer
Lou'd with that neerenesse of affection
To marry any, yet I mourne they should
Fall from their vertue, why may not Marwood
Iniure her goodnesse?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What, and damme his soule?
Shall I thinke any with his dying breath
Would shipwracke his last hope? he mixt it with
His praiers, when in the streame of his owne blood,
His soule was lanching forth.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: That circumstance takes away al suspition agen,
Where left you Marwood?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'the Parke.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Quite dead?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Hopelesse, his weapon might haue proued so happy,
To haue released me of a burthen too;
And but that man-hood, and the care of my
Eternity forbids, I would force out
That which but wearies me to carry it,
Vnwelcome life?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Would he were buried,
My feares perplex me for you; though none see
You fight, the circumstance must needes
Betray you: what's he. Enter a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I would borrow your eare in priuate.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We are but one to heare, his loue hath
Made him? to great a part of my affliction:
Speake it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: The body is taken thence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I cannot be deceiued sir: I beheld
Too plaine a demonstration of the place;
But he that suffred such a losse of blood,
Had not enough to maintayne life till this time,
Which way so ere his body was conuey'd:
I must conclude it short liu'd, I am sorry
I could not serue you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Sir,— I thanke you,
You deserue I should be gratefull: giues him mony.
It must be so— Exit Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: A Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Dare you trust him?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Yes, with my life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You haue done that already in your discouery.
Pray heauen he prooue your friend.
You must resolue for flight, ye shall take ship—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Will you ruine your selfe? there's no security—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: There is not Captayne,
Therefore Ile not change my ayre.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Vnlesse thou canst instruct me how to fly from
My selfe, for wheresoeuer else I wander,
I shall but carry my accuser with me.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I haue heard in Affricke, is a tree, which tasted
By trauailers, it breedes forgetfulnesse
Of their Country, canst direct me thither?
Yet 'twere in vaine, vnlesse it can extinguish,
And drowne the remembrance I am Beauford:
No— Ile not moue, let those poore things that dare not
Dye, obey their feares, I will expect my fate here.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This is wildnesse,
A desperate folly, pray be sensible:—
Whos's this, tis Gratiana.

div.stage: Enter Gratiana with a Cabinet of Iewels.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha, farwell.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You shall stay now a little.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I will not heare an accent, I shall loose
My memory, be charmed into beliefe
That she is honest with her voyce, I dare not
Trust my frailty with her.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: She speakes nothing,
Is all a weeping Nyobe, a statue,
Or in this posture, doth shee not present
A water Nymph, placed in the midst of some
Faire Garden, like a Fountaine to dispence
Her Christal streames vpon the flowers? which cannot
But so refresht, looke vp, and seeme to smile
Vpon the eyes that feed em:
Will she speake?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Though by the effusion of my teares, you may
Conclude, I bring nothing but sorrow with me,
Yet heare me speake, I come not to disturbe
Your thoughts, or with one bold and daring language
Say how vniust you make my sufferings:
I know not what
Hath raised this mighty storme to my destruction,
But I obey your doome, and after this,
Will neuer see you more. First I release
And giue you back your vowes; with them, your hart,
Which I had lock'd vp in my owne, and cherisht
Better, mine I'm sure does bleed to part with't,
All that is left of yours, this Cabinet
Deliuers backe to your possession,
There's euery iewell you bestowed upon me,
The pledges once of loue.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Pray keepe em.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: They are not mine, since I haue lost the opinion
Of what I was, indeed I haue nothing else,
I would not keepe the kisses, once you gaue me,
If you would let me pay them backe againe.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: All women is a laborinth, we can,
Measure the height of any starre, point out
All the dimensions of the earth, examine
The Seas large wombe, and sounds its subtle depth,
But arte will nere be able to finde out,
A demonstration of a womans heart,
Thou hast enough vndone me, make me not
More miserable, to beleeue thou canst be vertuous:
Farwell, enioy you this, I shall finde out
Another roome to weepe in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Lady I would aske you a rude question:
Are you a maide?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Do I appeare so Monstrous? no man will
Beleeue my iniury: has heauen forgot
To protect innocence, that all this while
It hath vouchsafed no miracle, to confirme
A Virgins honour?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I am answered:
I do beleeue shees honest; Oh that I could
But speake with Marwoods ghost now, and thou beest
In hell, I'de meete thee halfe way, to conuerse
One quarter of an houre with thee, to know
The truth of all things, thy Diuell Iaylour
May trust thee without a waiter, he has security
For thy damnation in this sinne alone,
I me full of pitty now, and spite of man-hood
Cannot forbeare, come Lady, I am confident,
I know not which way— that y'are vertuous—
Pray walke with mee, ile tell you the whole story;
For yet you know not your accuser.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I am an exile hence, and cannot walke
Out of my way, Beauford farwell, may Angels
Dwell round about thee, liue vntill thou find,
When I am dead, thou hast bin too vnkind. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: May I beleeue thee Milisent, that my father
Though hee giue such respect to him I hate,
Intenes no marriage? thou hast releast
My heart of many feares, that I was destin'd
To be a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: It had beene sinne
That Milisent should suffer you perplexe
Your noble soule, when it did consist in
His discouery, to giue a freedome
To your labouring thoughts, tis now no more a secret,
Your father makes a triall of your nature,
By giuing him such countenance.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: What thankes shall I giue?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Your vertue hath both vnseal'd
My bosome, and rewarded me.

sp.speaker: Iane
sp.l: Oh Milisent:
Thou hast deseru'd my gratitude; and I cannot
But in exchange of thy discouery
Giue to thy knowledge, what I should tremble
To let another heare; for I dare trust thee with it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: If I haue any skill
In my owne nature, shall nere deceiue
Your confidence, and thinke my selfe much honor'd,
So to be made your treasurer.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Tis a treasure,
And all the wealth I haue, my life, the summe
Of all my ioyes on earth, and the expectation
Of future blessings too depend vpon it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Can I be worthy of so great a trust?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Thou art, and shalt receiue it, for my heart
Is willing to discharge it selfe into thee:
Oh Milisent! though my father would ha beene
So cruell to his owne, to haue wished me marry
Him, twas not in the power of me obedience
To giue consent to't, for my loue already
Is dedicate to one, whose worth hath made
Me, but his steward of it, and although
His present fortune doth ecclipse his lustre,
With seeming condition of a seruant,
He has a minde deriued from honour, and
May boast himselfe a Gentle-man: is not
Thy vnderstanding guilty of the person
I point at? sure thou canst not choose but know him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Then looke vpon him Milisent.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: My master, mistresse Iane sent me before,
To say, be comes to visite you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: But thou art before him in acceptance, nay
You stand discouered here, in Milisent you may
Repose safe trust.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Her language makes me confident,
You are a friend.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: To both a seruant.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: I shall desire your loue.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: But where's this man of morgages?
We shall be troubled now

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: I left him chawing the cud, ruminating
Some speech or other, with which, he meanes to
Arrest you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He is entred.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I haue prepar'd her.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Fortune be my guide then.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: And she's a blind one.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p:
Mistresse Iane, I would talke with you in priuate, I haue fancied a businesse, I know you are witty, and loue inuention, tis my owne, and no-body else must heare it—
Be it knowne to all men by these presents.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: This is like to be a secret.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That I Iasper Rawbone Citizen, and House-keeper of London.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: A very poore one I'me sure.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Do owe to mistresse Iane, Lady of my thoughts, late of London Gentle-woman.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Is she not still a Gentle-woman?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Still a Gentle-woman good-man Coxe-combe? did I not say she was Lady of my thoughts? where was I now?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: At good-man Coxe-combe sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: — Do owe to mistresse Iane, Lady of my thoughts, late of London Gentle-woman, my true and lawfull heart of England— to be payd to his sayd mistresse, her executors, or assignes.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: To her executors? what will you pay your heart, when she is dead?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Tis none of my fault, and she will dye, who can helpe it? thou dost nothing but interrupt me: I say to be payd, to his sayde mistresse, her executors, or assignes, whensoeuer she demaund it, at the font-stone of the Temple—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Put it, the top of Paules and please you; your conceite wilbe the higher.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p:
Which payment to bee truely made and performed, I
bind, not my heires, but my body and soule for euer.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How your soule sir?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Peace foole, my soule will shift for it selfe, when I am dead that wilbe sure enough:— In witnesse whereof, I haue here-vnto put my hand and seale, which is a hansome spiny youth, with a bag of mony in one hand, a bond in the t'other, an Indenture betweene his legs, the last of the first merry moneth, and in the second yeare of the raigne of King Cupid.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Excellent! but in my opinion, you had better giue her possession of your heart, I do not like this owing: fayth plucke it out, and deliuer it in the presence of vs.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Thou talk'st like a puisne, I can giue her possession of it, by deliuery of two-pence wrapt vp in the wax, twill hold in Law man;— and how, and how d'ee like it? I could haue come ouer you with Verse, but hang Ballads, giue me Poeticall prose, euery Mounte-banke can time, and make his lines crye twang, though there be no reason in em.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: What Musique haue I heard?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Musique? Oh rare!

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: Hee has Medusaes noble countenance,
His haires do curle like soft and gentle Snakes:
Did euer puppy smile so? or the Asse
Better become his eares? oh generous beast
Of sober carriage, sure he's valiant too,
Those blood-shot eyes betray him, but his nose
Fishes for commendation.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: What does she meane Iasper?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: D'ee not see her loue sir? why she does doate vpon you, Which makes her talke so madly.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Forsooth I know you are taken with me, alas these things are naturall with me, when shall we be married forsooth?

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: With your licence sir—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: D'ee not obserue her? you must first procure a Licence.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: You shall heare more from mee, when I come agen— Iasper— Exit Rawbone hastily.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: My heart doth breath it selfe vppon your hand— Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Your father and Master Lodam—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I doe loue your daughter:— I thought it necessary to acquaint you first, because I would go about the businesse iudicially.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You obliege vs both.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ile promise you one thing.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ile bring your daughter no wealth.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Say you so: what then you promise her nothing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But I will bring her that which is greater then wealth.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My selfe.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: A faire ioynture.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, ile bring her more.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: It shu'not neede, no woman can desire more of a man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I can bring her good qualities, if she want any: I ha trauail'd for em.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The Languages.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You suspect shee will want tongue:— let me see— Parlez franzois monsieur.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Diggon a camrag.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: That's Welch.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pocas palabras.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: That's Spanish.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Troth I haue such a confusion of languages in my head, you must e'en take em as they come.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You may speake that more exactly— Hauelar spagniel Signior?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Serge-dubois,— Calli-mancho, et Perpetu-ana.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
There's stuffe indeede, since you are so perfect, Ile trust you for the rest. I must referre you sir vnto my daughter, if you can winne her faire opinion, my consent my happily follow: so
Shee is in presence—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Mercie Madame— Salutes Iane.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: This fellow lookes like the principall in Vsury, and this Rat followes him like a pittifull eight in the hundred:— come hither sirra, your name is Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: It is too true sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You did liue with master Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No sir, I did starue with him, and please you:
I could not liue with him.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: How doe you like your change?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Neuer worse.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Master Lodam wants no flesh.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But I doe:— I ha no Iustice sir, my leane master would eate no meate, and my fat master eates vp all— is your Worships house troubled with Vermin?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Something at this time.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Peace and ile catch a mouse then.— lies downe.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: My nephew turn'd Gentle-man Vsher.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Belfares daughter.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: 'Las poore Gentle-woman,
I compassionate her vnkind destiny.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Let vs intreat a word in priuate sir—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I cannot tell how you stand affected, but if you can loue a man, I know not what is wanting, greatnesse is a thing that your wisest Ladies haue an itch after: for my owne part I was neuer in loue before, and if you haue me not, neuer wilbee agen. Thinke on't betweene this and after dinner, I will stay o'purpose for your answere.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Y'are very short.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I wod not be kept in expectation aboue an houre, for loue is worse then a Lent to me, and fasting is a thing my flesh abhorres, if my doublet be not fil'd, I know who fares the worse for't. I would keepe my flesh to sweare by, and if you and I cannot agree vpon the matter, I would loose nothing by you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Y'are very resolute.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Euer while you liue, a fat man, and a man of resolution goe together: I doe not commend my selfe, but there are no such fiery things in nature.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Fiery?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Tis prou'd, put em to my action, and see, if they do not smoake it, they are men of mettle, and the greatest melters in the World, one hot seruice makes em rost, and they haue enough in em to bast a hundred— you may take a leane man, marry your selfe to famine, and beg for a great belly, you see what became of sir Iohns daughter:— come I would wish you be well aduis'd, there are more commodities in me, then you are aware of, if you and I couple, you shall fare like an Empresse.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: That will be somewhat costly.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not a token. I haue a priuiledge:— I was at the Tauerne tother day, i'the next roome I smelt hot Venison, I sent but a Drawer to tell the Company, one in the house with a great belly, long'd for a corner, and I had halfe a pasty sent me immediately: I will hold intelligence with all the Cookes i'the Towne, and what dainty, but I haue greatnesse enough to command?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I like it well:— be as wel-come heere, as at your Fathers. Milisent— make it your care to waite vpon this Gentlewoman, but conceale shee is our guest. I should reioyce to see this storme blowne ouer.— Nephew attend her to her Chamber. Exeunt Gratiana, Captaine, Milisent.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I ha bin about it— iustles Lodam, and fals downe.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: Next time you ride post, wind your horne, that one may get out a'the way.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What's the matter Iane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Tis guts, if I durst, my teeth waters to strike him.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What ha you done?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Let him take heed another time.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Take such an affront before your mistresse.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I haue a good stomacke—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: That's well sayd.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I could eate him.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Oh is it that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Let me alone, no-body hold me.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ile haue an action of battery.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Whorson mole-catcher—
Come not neere me Weezel.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Prethee Iasper do not thrust me vpon him—
I do not feare you sit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Agen shall I kicke thee to peeces.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let him baffull yee— to him— Hauer thrusts him vpon him.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I do not feare you.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Iane remooue your selfe.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Master Rawbone, I am sorry for your hurt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: She jeeres you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: For this time I am content with kicking of thee.

div.stage: As Lodam offers to goe out, Hauer puls him backe.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: My master desires another word w'ee sir.—
You must fight with him— To Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Who I fight?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You spider catcher, ha you not enough? you see I doe not draw.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: By this hand, you shall challenge him then, if hee dare accept it, Ile meete him in your clothes.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Will yee. Hum— I do not feare you— satisfaction—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: That's the word.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That's the word— youle meete me guts.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Meete thee by this flesh, if thou dost but prouoke me:— you do not challenge me— do not— d'ee long to be minc'd?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: At Finsbury—

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: At Finsbury.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: To morrow morning—

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: To morrow morning— you shall finde I dare fight.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: Say but such another word.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Finsbury, to morrow morning, there tis agen—

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I cannot contayne my laughter, ha, ha, ha. Exit

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: So, lets begone quickly, before he threaten me, you made mee challenge him, looke to't.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Feare not, I warrant you. Exeunt Raw & Hauer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sirra Nouerint, if I can but prooue, thou dost come with in three furlongs of a wind-mill, ile set one a top of Paules to watch thee— sha't forfeit thy soule, and ile cancell thy body worse then any debtor of thine did his obligation— hee's gone— and now I thinke vpon the matter, I haue somewhat the worst on't, for if I should kill him, I shall neuer bee able to flye, and hee has left a peece of his scull, I thinke, in my shoulder— whither am I bound to meet him, or no? I will consult some o'the sword men, and know whether it be a competent challenge— Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Has the Rat, your master that was, any spirit in him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Spirit? the last time hee was in the field, a boy of seauen yeares old, beate him with a Trap-sticke.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Saist thou so? I will meet him then, and hew him to peeces.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I haue an humble suite— if it be so, that you kill him, let me beg his body for an Anatomy, I haue a great mind to eate a peece on him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Tis granted, follow me, ile cut him vp I warrant thee. Exe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I haue a letter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I would forget that name, speake it no more.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: She is abus'd, and if you had not beene
Transported from vs, with your passion,
You would ha chang'd opinion, to haue heard
How well she pleaded.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: For her-selfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You might,
With little trouble gather from her teares
How cleare she was, which more transparent, then
The morning dew, or christall, fell neglected
Vpon the ground: some cunning Ieweller
To ha seene em scattred, would a thought some Princesse
Dropt em, and couetous to enrich himselfe,
Gathered them vp for Dyamonds.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You are then conuerted.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Oh you were too credulous.
Marwood has playd the Vilaine, and is damn'd for't:
Could but his soule be brought to heare her answere
The accusation, she wo'd make that blush,
And force it to confesse a treason, to
Her honour, and your loue.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You did beleeue her.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I did, and promis'd her to do this seruice,
She begd of me at parting, if she sent
A letter, to conuey it to your hand,
Pray read, you know not what this paper carries.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Has shee acquainted you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Not me, I guesse,
It is some secret, was not fit for my
Relation, it may be, worth your knowledge;
Do her that iustice, since you would not heare
What she could say in person, to peruse
Her paper.

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: It can bring nothing to take off
Th' offence committed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir you knew not
What satisfaction it contaynes;
Or what she may confesse in't: for my sake— Reads.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: To him that was— what?
Confident of her Vertue
Once an admirer, now a maurner for
Her absent goodnesse: she has made the change.
From her that was, would ha become this paper
Had she conseru'd her first immaculate whitenesse,
It had beene halfe prophane, not to salute
Her letter with a kisse, and touch it, with
More veneration then a Sybils leafe;
But now all Ceremony must be held
A superstition, to the blotted scrole,
O a more stained writer— Ile not reade:
If vnprepar'd, she win with her Discourse,
What must she do, when she has time, and study,
To apparrell her defence?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Deny her this.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Well, I will read it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here's Sir Iohn Belfare.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Say any thing t'excuse me, beet your care
That none approach the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: So, so, now vnrip the seale.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not speak with him, he must haue stronger guard
To keepe me out: where's Beauford?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Then there's a Villaine.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That's course language.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I must not spin it finer, till you make me
Vnderstand better, why my daughter, and
In her, my family is abus'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Shee has not then accus'd her selfe— Ile tell you,
I did expect your daughter would haue beene
My Virgin bride; but she reseru'd for me
The ruines of her honour, I wod not speake
I'the rude dialect, you may sooner collect,
An English.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is she not honest, will you
Make her then a whore?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Not I, her owne sinne made her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou lyest, nor can my age make me appeare
Vnworthy a satisfaction from thy sword.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Does not he call my young mistresse whore?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Keep me not from him Captaine he has in this
Giuen a fresh wound, I came t'expostulate,
The reason of a former suffering,
Which vnto this was charity, as thou art
A Gentle-man, I dare thee to the Combate:
Contemne not Beauford my gray haires, if t'hast
A Noble soule, keepe not this distance; meete me,
Thou art a Souldier: for heauens sake, permit me
Chastise the most vncharitable slander
Of this bad man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I neuer iniur'd you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not iniur'd me? what is there then in nature,
Left, to be cald an iniury? didst not mocke
Me, and my poore fond girle with marriage?
Till all things were design'd, the very day
When Hymen should haue worne his saffron robe:
My friends inuited, and prepar'd to call
Her Bride; and yet, as if all this could not
(Summ'd vp together) make an iniury:
Does thy corrupted soule at last conspire
To take her white name from her?— giue me leaue
To expresse a Father, in a teare, or two,
For my wrong'd child. O Beauford! thou hast rob'd
A father, and a daughter— but I wo not
Vsurpe heauens iustice, which shall punish thee
'Boue my weake arme; mayst thou liue, to haue
Thy heart as ill rewarded, to be a father
At my yeares, haue one daughter, and no more
Belou'd as mine, so mock'd, and then cald Whore.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Las good old man. Exit Bel. Isaac.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: My afflictions
Are not yet numbred in my fate, nor I
Held ripe for Death.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Now read the Letter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, it cannot make me know more misery. Reads.

Beauford, I dare not call thoe mine, though I could not hope, (while I was liuing,) thou wouldst beleeue my innocence, deny mee not this fauour after Death, to say I once lou'd thee— Ha death? Captaine is she dead?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I hope shee employd not me, to bring this newes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Yes, Death— ha?
Prethee read the rest: there's something
In my eyes, I cannot well distinguish
Her small Characters.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My Accuser by this time, knowes the reward of my iniurye Farewell, I am carrying my Prayers for thee to another World— her owne Martyr, drown'd Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Read all.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I haue.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: It cannot be, for when thou mak'st an end,
My heart should giue a tragicke period,
And with a loud sigh breake: drown'de
Twas no sinne aboue heauens pardon,
Though thou hadst beene false,
To thy first vow, and me, I wod not had
Thee dyed so soone: or if thou hadst affected
That death, I could ha drownd thee with my teares,
Now they shall neuer find thee, but be lost
Within thy watery Sepulcher.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Take comfort.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Art dead?
Then here ile Coffin vp my selfe, vntill
The Law vnbury me for Marwoods death,
I wonot hope for life, mercy sha' not saue
Him, that hath now a pattent for his Graue. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quarti. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Tis his command to whom I owe all seruice,
I should attend you.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Th'art too diligent:
I prethee leaue me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I should be vnhappy
To be offensiue in my duty; yet
Had I no charge vpon me, I should much
Desire to waite.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: On mee?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I know not why,
Your sorrow does inuite me.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Th'art too young,
To be acquainted wo't.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I know, it wod not
Become my distance, to dispute with you,
At what age, we are fittest to receiue
Our griefes impression.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Leaue me to my selfe—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I must, if you will haue it so. offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Me thought
I saw him drop a teare, come backe agen:
What should he meane by this vnwillingnesse
To part; he lookes, as he would make me leaue
My owne mis-fortune to pitty his:
Thy name?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I am called Milisent.

sp.speaker: Grat
sp.l: Dost thou put on that countenance to imitate
Mine? or hast a sorrow of thy owne, thou
Wouldst expresse by't.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Mine does become my fortune.
Yet yours does so exactly paint our misery
That he, that wanted of his owne, would mourne
To see your picture.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Mine is aboue
The common leuell of affliction.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Mine had no example to be drawne by,
I would they were a kin, so I might make
Your burden lesse by mine owne suffering.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I thanke thy loue.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And yet I prophesie,
There's something would make mine a part of yours,
Were they examin'd.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Passion makes thee wild now.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You haue encouraged me to boldnes, pardon
My ruder language.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Didst thou euer loue?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Too soone, from thence sprung my vnhappines.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: My affliction riper then my yeares,
Hath brought me so much sorrow, I doe not thinke
That I shall liue, to be a man.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I like thy sad expression, weele conuerse
And mingle stories.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I shall be too bold.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Wee lay aside distinctions, if our fates
Make vs alike in our mis-fortunes; yet
Mine will admit no paralell: ha! we are interrupted:
Lets with-draw, and ile begin.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You may commaund, and when
Your stories done, mine shall maintayne the Scene. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: To maintayne such blisse I will,
Wish to bee trans-formed still:
Nor wilt bee a shame in loue, reads,
Since I imitate but Ioue;
Who from heauen hath strayd, and in
A thousand figures worse then mine,
Woed a Virgin, may not I,
Then for thee a seruant trye:
Yes for such a mayde as thee,
Vary as many shapes as hee;
Rawbone cloathes my out-ward part,
But thy liuery my heart:
Hauer, ha: young Hauer?
