sp.p: This Letter I found in my Daughters prayer Booke, is this your Saint? how long ha they conspir'd thus? Report gaue out, hee was gone to trauaile: It seemes he stayes here for a Wind, and in the meane time would rigge vp my Daughter: hee is a Gentleman well educated; but his Fortune was consum'd by a prodigall father, ere he was ripe, which makes him I suspect; borrow this shape to court my Daughter; little does Rawbone thinke his seruaunt is his riuall: I finde the iugling, and will take order they shanot steale a marriage.
sp.l: Nephew, I ha newes for you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: For mee sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: You are a Souldier, there's a duell to
Be fought this morning, will you see't?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It does not sir become a Gentle-man
To be spectator of a fight, in which
Hee's not engag'd.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: You may behold it Cosen,
Without disparagement to your honor; Rawbone
Has challeng'd Mr. Lodam, the place Finsbury—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: They fight? a doublet, stuft with straw, aduancing
A bull-rush, were able to fright em both
Out a'their sences, tha' not soule enough
To skirmish with a field-mouse; they poynt a duell?
At Hogs-don, to shew fencing vpon Creame
And cake-bread, murder a quaking Custard,
Or some such daring enemy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Did not
Affaires of weight compell me to be absent,
I would not misse the sight, on't; for the Vsurer
Hath got his man Iasper t appeare for him
In his apparrell.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Iasper.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: For mirths sake
You may behold it, and let mee entreate,
At your returne, perfect relation
Of both their valours.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And Coze—
If it be possible, procure em hither
Before they shift, I much desire to see em.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Promise your selfe they shall: I will deferre
My conference with Gratiana, and
Intertayne this recreation.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: So: I haue a fancy,
This opportunity will giue it birth,
If all hit right, it may occasion mirth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Which part of my discourse compels thee to
This suffering?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Your pardon Lady, I
Did prophesie what now I finde, our stories
Haue dependance

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: How prethee?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That Marwood
Whom you report thus wounded had a neere
Relation to me, and twas my fortune
To come to close his eyes vp, and receiue
His last breath.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I know more then Beauford,
And dying he oblieg'd my loue to tell t'him
When ere wee met.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You beget wonder in me:
Did he suruiue his slander? there is hope
He did recant the iniury he did me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He did confirme, he had enioy'd your person,
And bad me tell Beauford hee left behind
A liuing witnesse of the truth he dyed for:
Naming a Gentle-woman Cardona,
That bred you in your fathers house, whom he
Affirm'd, betray'd your body to his lust.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Cardona?
Piety has forsaken earth:
Was euer woman thus betray'd to sinne,
Without her knowledge?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Wo'd he had not beene
My kinsman, I beginne to feare him:

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Wherein had I offended Marwood,
He should aliue, and dead so persecute
My fame? Cardona too i'the Conspiracy,
Tis time to dye then.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: My heart mournes for you
In the assurance of your innocence,
And were I worthy to direct you—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Has, malice
Found out another murderer?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Would you be pleas'd to heare me, I could poynt
You out a path, would bring you no repentance
To walke in, if (as I am confident)
Your goodnesse feares not, what Cardona can
Accuse your honour with, let her be
Examin'd, then her knowledge will quit you,
Or make your suffering appeare iust, this is
An easie triall, and since Marwood had
A stubborne soule, for though he were my kins-man
I preferre iustice, and held shame to checke
His owne report, women haue softer natures,
And things may be so manag'd, if there be
A treason, to enforce confession from her:
Would you please t'imploy me in this seruice,
And though vnworthy be directed by me,
I begge it from you, ile engage my being
You shall finde comfort in't.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Doe any thing;
But I am lost already.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You much honour me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Cam, see and if he be come yet, bring mee word hither.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I see one lying o'the ground—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is there so? lets steale way before we be discouered, I do not like when men lye perdue, beside, there may be three or foure of a heape, for ought we know: lets backe I say.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Tis a horse.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hang him iade, I knew it could bee nothing else: is the coast cleare Cameleon?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I see nothing but fiue or sixe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Fiue or sixe: treachery! an ambush, tis valour to runne.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: They bee Wind-mille.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And yet, thou wod'st perswade me, twas an ambush for me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come thou wert afraide, and the truth were knowne; but be valiant: I haue a sword; and if I doe draw. it shall— be against my will: is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And hee were betweene this and More-gate, you might sent him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If he come, some body shall smell ill favouredly, ere he and I part:— ha! by this flesh tis he; Cam, go tell him I am sicke.

div.stage: Enter Hauer, Rawbone, (hauing chang'd cloathes) Captaine.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: A brace of bullets to my heare.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Here can I stand and behold the Champions.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I haue expected you this two houres, which is more then I had one to all the men I ha fought withall, since I slew the high Germaine in Tutle.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Whorson, moale-cather.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Draw Spider.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Wellslye toade.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let vs conferre a little.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Conferre me no conferrings: I will haue no more mercy on thee, then an Infidell: and t'hadst beene wise, thou mightest ha kept thee at home, with thy melancholy Cat, that keepes thy Study, with whom thou art in Commons, and doest feede on Rats a Sundayes; then perhaps a legge or an arme, with thy Iewes eares had satisfied me, when I met thee next: draw I say, why doest not draw?

sp.speaker: Hau
sp.p: I come to giue you satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What with words?

Sirra Tartar, my Foxe shall scratch thy guts out, which I will send to the Beare-Garden: Doest heare Vsuring dog, ile tell thee my resolution. I doe meane to giue thee as many Wounds before I kill thee, as a Surgeons signe has; and when I am weary of skarrifying thy flesh, ile bore thy heart— which done: mark what I say; I will diuide thy quarters: obserue and tremble; then will I ha thee put into a tub or Barrell, and powder thee, and after three dayes in pickle, this thing that was thy seruant, this Cacodemon whom thou didst statue once, Cameleon, shall in reuenge of his pityfull famine, eate thee vp, deuoure thee, and grow fat i'the ribs agen with thy flesh. Mammon—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I hungrily thanke your Worship.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: What haue I scapt? aside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Which is more, after thou art dead, I wonot leaue thy
soule quiet, ile torment thy Ghost: for I will streight to thy house where I will breake open thy Chests, lin'd with white and yellow mettle, which I will cast away on pious vses: then summon all thy debtors by a Drum, and giue em in, all their Bills, Bonds, Euidences, Indentures, Defesances, Morgages, Statutes.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I shall be vndone.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And there were a million on em.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ile home, and shut vp my doores, for feare he kill Iasper and vse me so indeede.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: If thou doest offer to looke home agen, till they ha done, ile cut thee off at thigh.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ah—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Draw I say.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Since there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: His sword appeares Cam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If he were a coward you were able to coniure a spirit into him, with those threatnings.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pox a'my dulues: dost heare scoundrell, if I should incline to mercy, what submission? ha? let mee see— I, I, liue, thou shalt vpon thy knees confesse thy rascality, and aske me forgiuenesse in priuate, in the presence of mistresse Iane, and the twelue Companies which at thy charge shalbe feasted that day, in More-fields.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: That must not be.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Then say when thou art dead, thou wert offred conditions for thy life: Cam, thou shalt feed, and feed high Cameleon,— let me see;— come tis my foolish nature to ha compassion o'thee, I know th'art sorry, shat onely confesse thy selfe a rascall vnder thy hand then, and stay my in ended reuenge which else would ha beene immortall.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let me consider.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oho Cam.—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Both cowards, we shall haue no skirmish.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p:
Now I thinke on't, what if my man Iasper, should be valiant and kill Lodam— umh? what pickle were I in: worse-worse, hee'le runne away, I shall bee taken and hang'd for the Conspiracy. Puls Haue, by the sleeue. r
Ah— Iasper, rogue that I was, where were my braines to challenge him— he wonot heare— a stubborne knaue, he lookes as if he meant to kill: ah Iasper.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I ha seene a dogge looke like him, that has drawne a Wicker bottle, ratling about the streetes, and leering on both sides, where to get a quiet corner to bite his tayle off.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I doe imagine my selfe apprehended already: now the Constable is carrying me to New-gate— now, now. Ime at the Sessions house, i'the Docke:— now I'me cald— not guilty my Lord:— the Iury has found the indicement Billa vera— now, now comes my sentence.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I am resolu'd sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ha.—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You shall haue what acknowledgement, this pen of steele will draw out in your flesh, with red inke, and no other, deare master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Now I'me i'the Cart, riding vp Holborne in a two wheel'd Chariot, with a guard of Halberdiers: there goes a proper fellow sayes one: good people pray for me: now I am at the three Wodden stilts.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is this Rawbone the Coward?
Doest heare thing— consider what thou doest, come among friends, thy word shall bee as good as a note vnder thy hand, tempt not my fury— wod I were off, with asking him forgiuenesse.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Hey! now I feele my toes hang i'the Cart:
Now tis drawne away, now, now, now,
I am gone— turnes above.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You must shew your fencing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hold: I demaund a parlee.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tis not for your reputation to deale with a
Gentle-man vpon vnequall termes.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Where lye the oddes?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Howes this?

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: Examine our bodies:
I take it I am the fairer marke, tis a disaduantage: feede til you be as fat as I, and ile fight w'ee as I am a Gentle-man.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: It sha not serue your turne. Fight.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hold, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I'm dead, I'm dead.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Whorson puffe-paste, how he winkes and barkes: How now Gentle-men, master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Captayne, shud a come but a little sooner, and ha seene good sport, by this flesh hee came vp handsomely to me; a pritty sparke faith Captayne.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But if you be his friend, runne for a Surgeon for him, I haue hurt him vnder the short ribs, beside a cut or two ith' shoulder: would I were in a Millars sacke yonder, though I were ground for't, to be quit onem.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You wonot vse me thus?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I were best deliuer my sword ere I be compeld too't— a pritty fellow, and one that will make a souldier, because I see th'ast a spirit, and canst vse thy Weapon, ile bestow a dull blade vppon thee Squirrell.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Deliuer vp your Weapon:

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: In loue in loue Captaine, hea's a sparke a my reputation, and worthy your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Thou mully-puffe, were it not iustice to kicke thy guts out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: When I am dis-arm'd.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Take't, agen you spunge—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What? when I haue geent thee: tis at thy seruice, and it were a whole Cutlers shop: be confident.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: My Ague has not left mee yet, there's a grudging a'the halter still:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Master Rawbone, I repent my opinion of your Cowardize.
I see you dare fight, and shall report it to my Cosen:
You shall walke home, shee'le take it as an honor,
And present your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Iasper, lets go home and shift, do not go— honest Iasper.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You will be pratling sirra— Ile waite vpon you Captayne: Master Lodam—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will accompany thee, th'art noble, and fit for my conuersation, honest master Rawbone— a poxe vpon you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay, you shal waite a your master with his leaue, good Iasper

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How now Iasper? Exeunt.

div.stage: Musicke: A Table set forth with two Tapers: Seruants placing Ewe, Bayes, and Rosemary, &c.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Are these the hearbes you strow at Funerals.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Tis well, I commend your care,
And thanke yee; yee haue exprest more duty
Im not enquiring wherefore I commaund
This strange employment, there in the very
Act of your obedience: my chamber
Lookes like the Spring now? ha' yee not arte enough
To make this Ewe tree grow here, or this Bayes?
The embleme of our victory in Death?
But they present that best when they are wither'd:
Haue you beene carefull that no day breake in
At any Window, I would dwell in night,
And haue no other star-light but these tapers:

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: If any aske to speake with you,
Shall I say, you are abroad.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: No, to all do enquire with busie faces
Pale or disturb'd, giue free accesse. Exit ser.
What do I differ from the dead? would not
Some fearefull man or woman seeing me,
Call this a Church-yard, and imagine me
Some wakefull apparition 'mong the graues;
That for some treasures buried in my life,
Walke vp and downe thus? buried? no twas drownd,
I cannot therefore say, it was a chest,
Gratiana had nere a Coffin, I haue one
Spacious enough for both on's, but the waues
Will neuer yeeld too't, for it may bee they
Soone as the northerne Wind blowes cold vppon em,
Will freeze themselues to marble ouer her,
Least she should want a tombe:
Thy businesse.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Hee dyed this morning:
A friend of his and yours did practise on him
A little Surgery, but in vayne; his last
Breath did forgiue you: but you must expect
No safety from the Law: my seruice sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I haue left direction, that it cannot misse me:
And hadst thou come to apprehend me for't?
With as much ease thou mightst; I am no states-man
Officious, seruants makes no sutors waite
My doores vnguarded; tis no laborinth
I dwell in; but I thanke thy loue, there's something
To reward it: iustice cannot put on
A shape to fright me.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: I am sorry sir,
Your resolution carries so much danger. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What can life bring to me, that I should court it:
There is a period in nature, ist not
Better to dye and not be sicke; worne in
Our bodies, which in imitation
Of ghosts, grow leane, as if they woo'd at last
Be immateriall too; our blood turne ielly
And freeze in their cold channell, let mee expire
While I haue heat and strength to tug with death
For Victory.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You may disburden there,
But gently, tis a chest of value, mistresse—
Ile giue him notice, where is Beauford?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What place d'ee call this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Tis a Bridall chamber.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: It presents horrour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha you anything
To say to me?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Proceede.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I come to visite you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You are not welcome then.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I did suspect it, and haue therfore brought
My assurance wo'me, I must require
Satisfaction for a kinsmans death,
One Marwood.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Your valour was not noble,
It was a course reward to kill him for
His friendship: I come not with a guard of
Officers to attach your person, it
Were too poore and formall, the instrument
That sluc'd his soule out, I had rather shud
Sacrifice to his ashes, and my sword
Shall do't, or yours be guilty of another,
To waite vppon his ghost.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Young man be not
Too rash without the knowledg how our quarrel
Rise to procure thy selfe a danger.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Make it
Not your feare, I haue heard the perfect story,
And ere I fight with thee shat see thy errour;
Acknowledge thou hast kild a friend, I bring
A perspectiue to make those things that lye
Remote from sence, familiar to thee, nay
Thou shat confesse thou knowst the truth of what
Concernes him, or Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: When my soule
Throwes off this vpper Garment, I shall know all.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Thou shat not number many minutes, know
'Twas my mis-fortune to close vp the eyes
Of Marwood, whose body I vow'd neuer
Should to the earth without reuenge; or mee
Companion to his graue: I ha therefore brought it
Hither, tis in this house.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: His pale corpes
Shall witnesse my affection.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou didst promise
To informe me of Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And thus briefly:
Marwood reueal'd at death another witnesse
Of his truth, for Cardona hee corrupted
To betray Gratiana to him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha Cardona!
Heauen continue her among the liuing,
But halfe an houre.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I ha sau'd yee trouble,
Shee waites without, in your name I procur'd
Her presence, as you had affaires with her
She's vnprepar'd, a little terrour will
Enforce her to confesse the truth of all things.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Thou doest direct well.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Still remember Beauford
I am thy lenemy, and in this doe but
Prepare thy conscience of misdeede to
Meete my iust anger.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I am all wonder. Milisent bring in Cardona.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He's now at opportunity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir you sent
To speake with me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come neerer, I heare say
You are Baud; tell me how goe Virgins
I'th sinfull market; nay I must know hell-cat
What was the price you tooke for Gratianaes:
Did Marwood come off roundly with his wages:
Tell me the truth, or by my fathers soule
Ile digge thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Helpe.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Let me not heare
A syllable that has not referrence
To my question— or—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ile tell you sir:
Marwood—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Did vitiously affect her:
Won with his gifts and flatteries, I promis'd
My assistance, but I knew her vertue was not
To bee corrupted in a thought.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Therefore—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What d'ee study—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hold— I would deliuer
The rest into your eare, it is too shamefull
To expresse it louder then a whisper—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: With what vnwillingnes, we discouer things
Wee are asham'd to owne: Cardona shudst
Ha vs'd but halfe this feare in thy consent.
And thou hadst nere beene guilty of a sinne
Thou art so loath to part with though it be
A burden to thy soule: how boldly would
Our innocence plead for vs; but shas done.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Then was Gratianaes honor sau'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Vntouch'd.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Where am I lost: this story is more killing
Then all my iealousies: Oh Cardona
Goe safe from hence, but when thou com'st at home,
Locke thy selfe vp and languish, till thou dye
Thou shalt meete Marwood, in a gloomy shade,
Giue backe this salary, Exit Cardona.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Haue I made good
My promise, do you finde your errour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: No I ha found my horror— has the chast
And innocent Gratiana drown'd her selfe?
What satisfaction can I pay thy ghost?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Now doe me right sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Shee's gone for euer,
And can the earth still dwell a quiet neighbour
To the rough Sea, and not it selfe bee thaw'd
Into a riuer; let it melt to waues
From hence-forth, that beside th'inhabitants,
The very Genius of the World may drowne,
And not accuse me for her: Oh Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Reserue your passion, and remember what
I come for.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How shall I punish my vniust suspition?
Death is too poore a thing to suffer for her:
Some spirit guide mee where her body lyes
Within her watery vrne, although seal'd vp
With frost, my teares are warme and can dissolue it,
To let in mee, and my repentance to her.
I would kisse her cold face into life agen
Renew her breath with mine, on her pale lip
I do not thinke, but if some artery
Of mine were open'd, and the crimson flood
Conuay'd into her veines, it would agree
And with a gentle gliding steale it selfe
Into her heart, inlif'ne her dead faculties,
And with a flattery, tice her soule agen,
To dwell in her faire tenement.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You loose
Your selfe in these wild fancies; recollect
And doe mee iustice.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I am lost indeede,
With fruitlesse passion: I remember thee
And thy designe agen; I must account
For Marwoods death ist not? alas thou art
Too young, and canst not fight, I wish thou wert
A man of tough and actiue sinewes, for
Thy owne reuenge sake, I would prayse thee for
My death, so I might fall but nobly by thee:
For I am burden'd with a weight of life—
Stay, didst not tell me thou hadst brought hither
The body of young Marwood—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Since a mistake, not malice did procure
His ill fate, I will but drop one funerall
Teare vpon his wound, and soone finish
To doe thee right.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Yee shall. A coffin brought in.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Does this enclose his corpes? how little roome
Doe wee take vp in death, that liuing, know
No bounds? here without murmurring wee can
Be circumscrib'd, it is the soule, that makes vs
Affect such wanton, and irregular pathes;
When that's gone, wee are quiet as the earth,
And thinke no more of wandring: oh Marwood
Forgiue my anger, thy confession did
Inuite thy ruine from me, yet vppon— Opens.
My memory forsake me, tis Gratiana's
Spirit, hast thou left thy Heauenly dwelling
To call me hence? I was now comming to thee:
Or but commaund more hast, and I will count it
No sinne to strike my selfe, and in the streame
Of my owne blood to imitate how thou
Didst drowne thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I am liuing Beauford.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I know thou art immortall.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Liuing as thou art.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Good angels doe not mocke mortality.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And came—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: To call me to my answere how I durst
Suspect thy chastity, ile accuse my selfe
And to thy iniur'd innocence giue me vp
A willing sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Oh my Beauford, now
I am ouer-blest for my late sufferings;
I haue sollicited my Death with prayers:
Now I would liue to see my Beauford loue me.
It was thy friend induc'd me to that letter,
To finde if thy suspition had destroy'd
All seedes of loue.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Art thou not dead indeede,
May I beleeue? her hands is warme,— shee breathes
Agen— and kisses as she wont to doe
Her Beauford, art Gratiana? Heauen
Let me dwell here vntill my soule exhale.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: One sorrow's cur'd Milisent begone,
Thou hast bin too long absent from thy owne. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Oh my ioy rauisht soule, but where's the youth
Brought mee this blessing? vanisht Gratiana
Where is hee? I would hang about his necke
And kisse his cheeke, he we not leaue me so:
Gone? sure it was some angell, was hee not,
Or doe I dreame this happinesse, wot not thou
Forsake mee to?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Oh neuer.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Within there—
Bid the young man returne, and quickly, least
My ioy aboue the strength of natures sufferance,
Kill me before I can expresse my gratitude:
Ha yee brought him?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Mr. Beauford, I am sorry wee are
Commanded to apprehend your person.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Officers ha?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: You are suspected to haue slaine a
Gentle-man, one Marwood.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Haue I still my essence ha?
I had a ioy was able to make man
Forget he could be miserable.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: If ere extreamities did kill, wee hath
Shall dye this very minute.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You shanot goe.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.l: Our authority will force him.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Y'are villaines, murderers:
Oh my Beauford!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Leaue me Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Neuer, ile dye with thee.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What can wee say vnto our misery,
Sau'd in a tempest that did threaten most,
Arriu'd the harbour, ship, and all are lost.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: To the next Iustice. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quinti. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Whether art fled Gratiana? that I can
Conuerse with none to tell mee thou art still
A mortall? taken hence by miracle?
Though angels should intice her hence, to heauen,
She was so full of piety, to her father,
She would first take her leaue.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: There he is sir, he cannot choose but talke idly,
For he has not slept since the last great mist.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mist?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I sir, his daughter, my young mistresse went away in't, and we can heare no tale nor tydings of her, to tell you true, I would not disgrace my old master, but hee is little better then mad.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Vnhappy Gentle-man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Tis so, hee murder'd her;
For he that first would rob her of her honor,
Would or feare after-ward to kill Gratiana,
He shall be arrang'd for't;— but where shall wee
Get honest men enough to make a Iury?
That dare be conscionable, when the Iudge
Lookes on, and frownes vpon the Verdict, men
That will not be corrupted, to fauour
A great man euidence, but preferre iustice
To ready mony? oh this age is barren—

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Master Beauford's newly
Apprehended for some fact, and carried
Fore Iustice Landby, in my passage hither
I met him guarded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Guarded for what?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Some did whisper hee had kild—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Gratiana.
sp.p: Oh my girle, my Gratiana,— Isaac, Beauford is taken, tis apparent he hath slayne my daughter, and shanot I reuenge her Death? Ile prosecute the Law with violence agaynst him, not leaue the Iudge, till hee pronounce his sentence, then Ile dye, and carry Gratiana the newes before him. Follow me— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I expect Iane thou wot reward my care
With thy obedience, he's young and Wealthy,
No matter for those idle ceremonies
Of wit and court-ship.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Doe I heare my father?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: He will maintaine thee gallant, City wiues
Are fortunes darlings, gouerne al, their husbands
Variety of pleasure, and apparell
When some of higher title are oft faine
To pawne a Lady-ship: thou shat haue Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Vertue forbid it, you are my father sir,
And lower then the earth I haue a heart
Prostrates it selfe, I had my being from you,
But I beseech you, take it not away
Agen, by your seuerity.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How's this? I like it well. aside.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: You haue read many lectures to me, which
My duty hath receiu'd, and practiz'd, as
Precepts from heauen, but neuer did I heare
You preach so ill, you heretofore directed
My study to bee carefull of my fame,
Cherish desert, plant my affection on
Noblenesse, which can onely be sufficient
To make it fruitefull, and d'ce counsell now
To marry a disease?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Good! my owne girls—
What ist you sayd? ha?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: For the man himselfe
Is such a poore and miserable thing—

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: But such another word, and I take off
My blessing: how now Iane?

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: Alas, I feare
He is in earnest, marry me to my graue,
to that you shall haue my consent, oh do not
Enforce mee to be guilty of a false
Vow, both to Heauen and Angels; on my knees—

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Humble your heart, rise and correct your sullennesse,
I am resolu'd, would you be sacrific'd
To an vnthrift, that wil dice away his skinne,
Rather then want to stake at Ordinaries?
Consume what I haue gather'd at a breake-fast,
Or mornings draught? and when you ha teem'd for him
Turne Semptresse to find milke and clouts for babies:
Foote stockings, to maintaine him in the Compter?
Or if this fayle, erect a bandy Citadell,
Well man'd, which fortified with demy-Cannon
Tobacco pipes, may raise you to a fortune,
Together with the traile—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Oh my cruell starres!

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Starre me no starres, ile haue my will—

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: One minute hath ruin'd all my hope, Milisent
Was cruell thus to mocke me.

div.stage: Enter Captayne, Hauer, Lodam, Rawbone, and Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Vnde— Cap. and Iust, whisper.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You heare, now he talkes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But I ha found the way, tis but procuring
Acquaintance with the fore-man of the Iury,
The Sessions bell-weather, he leades the rest
Like sheepe when hee makes a gap, they follow
In huddle to his sentence.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Speake to him sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: God saue you sir Iohn Belfare.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am a little serious— do not trouble mee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: D'ee not know me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I neyther know, nor care for you, vnlesse
You can bee silent.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I me your neighbour—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Master Doctor—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Away foole.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No sir, a Physition.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A Physition? can you cure my daughter?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I sir, where is shee?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Cannot you find her out by arte? a good
Physition, shud be acquainted with the Starres:
Prethee erect a figure, graue Astronomer,
Sh'at ha the minute she departed; turne
Thy Ephemerides a little, ile lend
Thee Ptolomy, and a nest of learned Rabbies
To iudge by: tell me whither she be a liue,
Or dead, and thou shalt bee my Doctor, ile
Giue thee a round per Annum pension,
And thou shalt kill me for it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: He has a strange De lyrium.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A Vertigo in's head.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: In his head.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What sayes the Rauen?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: He sayes, you haue two hard words in your head sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Haue you forgot me sir, I was but late
Familiar to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.l: Ha'your pardon gentle sir I know you now,
Impute it to my griefe, t'hath almost made mee
Forget my selfe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I come to visite you.
And cannot but bee sorry, to behold
You thus afflicted.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Doctor I am sicke,
I'me very sicke at heart losse of my daughter
I feare, will make me mad, how long d'ee thinke
Mans nature able to resist it, can
Your loue or arte prescribe your friend a Cordial?
No, no, you cannot.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sir, bee comforted.
Wee haue our manly vertue giuen vs,
To exercise in such extreames as these.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As these? why do you know what tis to
Loose a daughter? you conuerse with men, that
Are diseas'd in body; punish'd with a gout
Or feauer: yet some of these are held
The shames of physicke, but to th'mind you can
Apply no salutary medicine:
My daughter sir, my daughter—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was too blame
To leaue you so, loose not your wisedome for
Your daughters want of piety.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Speake well
A'th dead, for liuing shee would not be absent
Thus from mee, shee was euer dutifull
Tooke pleasure in obedience: oh my child,
But I haue strong suspition, by whom
She's made away. Beauford—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.l: He that pretended marriage— he gaue her
A wound before.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Iasper? what case am I in?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Be wise and keep your counsell, is not all for your honor?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Lady, I hope by this time, you are able to distinguish
A difference betweene Rawbone and my selfe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I finde little.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You shall doe noble sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Mr. Rawbone, the onely man in my wishes:
My nephew giues you valiant, your merit
Ore-ioyes me, and to shew how much I value
Your worth my daughter yours, ile see you
Married this morning ere we part, receiue him
Into your bosome Iane, or loose me euer.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: I obey sir: will my father cozen himselfe?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Ha, doe I dreame?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Dreame quotha, this is a pritty dreame.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Master Lodam, I hope you'le not repine at his fortune.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: But Rawbone will pine, and repine if this be not a dreame?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I allow it, and will dine with you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Iasper: no, will no body know me?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Let's loose no time, I haue no quiet tell
I call him sonne.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Master Iustice, do me right,
You do not know who I am— I am—

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: An asse sir, Are you not? what make you pratling?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Sir,—
Noble Captaine, a word, I am—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Coxecombe.
Your man is fancy sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then I am a— sleepe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I forget Gratiana

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Cosen, you shall supply my place at Church, while I prepare for your returne, some guests wee must haue— nay, nay haste, the morne growes old, wee'le ha't a Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Here's a blessing beyond hope.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Sure I am sleepe, I will cene walke with 'em till my dreame be out.

div.stage: Enter Beuford, Officers, Marwood disguised, Keeper, Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Mr. Beauford, welcome and Gratiana—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You will repent your curtesie, I am
Presented an offender to you.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Yes, and please your worship, he is accus'd.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Sir, you haue charity, beleeue em not,
They doe conspire to take away his life.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: May it please you vnderstand, he has kild
A Gentle-man, one Marwood, in our Parke,
I found him wounded mortally, though before
He dyed, he did confesse.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Vrge it no farther,
Ile saue the trouble of examination,
And yeeld my selfe vp guilty.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: For heauens sake
Beleeue him not, hee is an enemy
To his owne life; deare Beauford, what d'ee meane
To cast your selfe away, y'are more vnmercifull
Then those that doe accuse you, then the Law
It selfe, for at the worst, that can but finde
You guilty at the last, too soone for me
To bee deuided from you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh Gratiana, I call heauen to witnesse,
Though my mis-fortune made mee thinke before,
My life a tedious and painefull trouble,
My very soule a luggage, and too heauy
For me to carry, now I wish to liue,
To liue for thy sake, till my haire were siluer'd
With age; to liue till thou wodst ha me dye,
And were a weary of me: For I neuer
Could by the seruice of one life, reward
Enough thy loue, nor by the suffering
The punishment of age and time, do pennance
Sufficient for my iniury, but my fate
Hurries me from thee, then accept my death
A satisfaction for that sinne, I could not
Redeeme aliue, I cannot but confesse
The accusation.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Belfare, and Isaac.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Iustice, iustice, I will haue iustice:
Ha Gratiana!

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Oh my deare father—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Art a liue, oh my ioy, it growes
To mighty for me, I must weepe a little
To saue my heart—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My young mistresse aliue.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: If euer you lou'd Gratiana, plead for Beauford,
H'as beene abus'd, by a villaine, alls discouer'd,
W'aue renew'd hearts, and now I feare, I shall
Loose him agen, accus'd here for the death
Of Marwood, that was cause of all our suffering.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I ha not wept enough for ioy Gratiana
That th'art aliue yet— I vnderstand nothing
Beside this comfort.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Deere sir recollect,
And second me.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: The fact confest, all hope
Wilbe a pardon sir may be procur'd:
Sir Iohn— y'are come in a sad time.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What is the worst you charge him with?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: He has slaine a Gentle-man.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: No common trespasse.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He has done iustice.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: A publicke benefite to his Country in't.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Killing a man? her sorrow ouer-throwes
Her reason.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Heare me, Marwood was a Villaine,
A rebell vnto vertue, a prophaner
Of friendships sacred lawes, a murderer
Of virgin chastity, against whose malice
No innocence could hope protection;
But like a Bird grip'd by an Eagles talent,
It growing dyes.
What punishment can you inflict on him,
That in contemp of nature, and religion,
Inforces breach of loue, of holy vowes?
Sets them at warre whose hearts were married
In a full congregation of Angels:
I know you will not say, but such deserue
To dye yet Marwood being dead, you reach
Your fury to his heart, that did this benefit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh Gratiana if I may not liue
To enjoy thee here, Il would thou hadst beene dead
Indeede for in a little time, we shu'd
Ha met each other in a better World?
But since I go before thee, I will carry
Thy prayse along, and if my soule forget not,
What it hath lou'd, when it conuerst with men,
I wil so talke of thee among the blest.
That they shalbe in loue with thee, and descend
In holy shapes, to woe thee to come thither,
And be of their society doe not veile thy beauty
With such a shower, keepe this soft raine,
To water some more lost, and barren garden,
Least thou destroy the spring, which nature made
To be a wonder in thy cheeke

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Where is Marwoods body?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A liue!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Ha Marwood?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A liue, as glad to see thee, as thou art
To know thy selfe acquitted for my death;
Which I of purpose by this honest friend,
To whose cure, I owe my life, made you beleeue,
I increase our ioy at meeting: for you Lady,
You are a woman,— yet you might ha beene
Lesse violent in your pleading, do not
Engage me past respects of mine, or your own honor.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Mine is aboue thy malice, I haue a breast
Impenetrable, 'gainst which, thou soundly ayming,
Thy arrowes, but recoile into thy bosome,
And leaue a wound.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Friend we haue found thy errour—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let it be mine, we haue had stormes already.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Tell me iniurious man for in this presence
You must acquit the honour you accus'd,
Discharge thy poyson here, inhumane Traytor—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Thou wo't aske her now forigvenes, she's al chastitie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why d'ee tempt me thus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It was ill done sir—

sp.speaker: Iust
sp.l: Accuse her to her face.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So so, you see, I am silent still.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: You are too full of guilt to excuse your trechery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then farwell all respect, and heare me tell
This bold and insolent woman, that so late
Made triumph in my death.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Oh sir proceede not,
You do not declare your selfe of generous birth,
Thus openly to accuse a Gentle-woman,
Were it a truth.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He may throw soyle at heauen,
And as soone staine it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sirra boy, who made you so peremptory
He would be whipt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: With what? I am not arm'd
You see, but your big language would not fright
My youth, were it be friended with a sword;
You should find then I would dare to proue it
A falsehood, on your person.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How now Milisent?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hath my loue made mee thus ridiculous?
Beauford, that you will suffer such a boy
To affront me? then against all the world
I rise an enemy, and defie his valour
Dares iustifie Gratiana vertuous.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Beleeue your eyes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My daughter aliue?
Oh my deare heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are come opportunely,
Cardona speake the truth, as thou wouldst not
Eate my poinard, is not Gratiana
A sinnefull woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What meanes Marwood, ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am in a laborinth?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hold, I confesse—
You neuer did enioy Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let not our shame be publicke, sir, you shall
Haue the whole truth, oh that my teares were able
To wash my sinne away— won with your promises,
I did, in hope to marke my self a fortune,
And get a husband for my childe, with much
Blacke oratoury, woe my daughter to
Supply Gratianaes bed, whom with what
Circumstance, you enioy'd, that you beleeu'd
It was the virgin you desir'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am at a confasion, where's this daughter?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: She with the feare (as I conceiue) of her
Dishonour, taking a few iewels with her,
Went from me, I know not whither, by this time
Dead if not more vnhappy in her fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Into how many sinnes hath lust engag'd me?
Is there a hope you can forgiue, and you,
And she whom I haue most dishonor'd
I neuer had a conscience till now,
To be grieu'd for her, I will hide my selfe
From all the World.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Stay sir—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You heare this Beauford, father—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This she confest to me, though I conceal'd
From thee the errour, Marwood dead, their shame
Would not ha giuen my life aduantage, now
We haue ore-come the malice of our fate:
I hope you'le call me sonne.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Both my lou'd children.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I congratulate your ioy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beauford, Gentle-men,
This is a woman, Lucibol your daughter,
The too much iniur'd maide: oh pardon me,
Welcom both to my knowledge, and my heart.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: Oh my childe.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: My seruant prooue a woman?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You le marry her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall begin my recompence:
Lead you to Church we'le find the Priest more worke.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: He has done some already, for by this time
I haue a daughter married to young Hauer.
That walk'd in Rawbones liuery,— they'r return'd.

div.stage: Enter Captaine, Hauer, Iane, Lodam, and Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Father your pardon, though you meant me not
Your sonne, yet I must call your daughter, wife:
Here I resigne my Citizen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Young Hauer.

sp.speaker: Iust
sp.l: My blessing on you both,
I meant it so: a letter tooke off this
Disguise before; nay here are more couples,
Enough to play at Barly-breake.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Master Lodam, you and I are in Hell,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: You and I are friends.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I knew, by instinct, I had no quarell to thee:
Art thou Rawbone?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I am not drunke—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, but thou art disguis'd shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I wonot beleeue, I am awake:
This is not possible.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Leaue off to wonder Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sure this is a dreame.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: As sure, as you are there Captayne, 'las wee doe but walke and talke in our sleepe, all this while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I to dinner bullies.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: D'ee heare Gentle-men, before you go, does no-body know me? who am I? who am I?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You are master Rawbone fit, that would haue married my daughter, that is now wise, I take it, to this Gentle-man, your seeming seruant.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Dreame on, dreame on: Iasper, make much a'the wench now th'ast got her, am not I finely guld?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I thinke so.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Dreame on together, a good iest yfaith, he thinkes all this is true now.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Are not you then, awake fit?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: No marry am I not sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What d'ee thinke a'that sir. kickes him.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That sir? now do I dreame that I am kickt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You doe not feele it then.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Kicke, kicke your hearts out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Say you so, let my foote be in too then.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Sure I shall crye out in my sleep— what a long night tis.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Set on.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I, I, we may come backe, and take him napping.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come Gratiana,
My soule best halfe, lets tye the sacred knot,
So long deferr'd, neuer did two louers,
Meet in so little time so many changes;
Our Wedding day is come, the sorrowes past
Shall giue our present ioy more heauenly tast. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rawbone.
sp.p: GEntle-men: Pray he fauourable to wake a Foole Dormant I mongst yee; I ha beene kickt, and kicke to that purpose, may be, they knockt at the wrong doore, my braines are a sleepe in the Garret. I must appeale from their feete to your hands, there is no way but one, you must clap me, and clap mee soonely d'ee heare, I shall hardly come to my selfe else.

lg.l: Oh since my case without you desperate stands,
Wake me with the loud Musicke of your hands.
